themes.title: Southeast Asia and Cultural Connections
points: Ceramics were made specifically for export to Southeast Asia, showing how cultures share and influence each other.

Peranakan Chinese communities in the Straits Settlements used colorful ceramics with pinks, greens, and yellows to celebrate their traditions. These colors are cheerful and eye-catching—what colors make you feel happy?
Chinese blue-and-white ceramics were popular in Southeast Asia. These designs traveled across the ocean, just like stories and songs!

themes.title: Symbolism and Storytelling
points: Many ceramics were decorated with auspicious symbols, which are like lucky charms. Can you think of something you believe brings good luck?
Animals and flowers were common designs, like in Northern Song silk tapestries. These patterns tell stories about nature—what's your favorite animal or flower?
The bright colors and symbols on ceramics were used to celebrate rituals and special occasions. Imagine decorating something for a party—what would you draw?

themes.title: Materials and Techniques
points: Southern Song porcelain has a white-green glaze, which feels smooth and cool to the touch. Imagine running your fingers over it—how do you think it feels?
Polychrome ceramics use many colors, like a rainbow. Artists carefully painted these designs—what colors would you use if you were painting a plate?
Ceramics are made from clay and baked in a kiln to make them hard and shiny. It's like baking cookies but much hotter!

themes.title: Mythical and Cultural Imagery
points: Northern Song tapestries often show animals surrounded by flowers, creating magical scenes. Imagine a mythical creature—what would it look like?
The designs on these objects often tell stories about rituals and traditions. Think about a special tradition in your family—how would you show it in art?
The bright colors and patterns make these objects feel alive and exciting, like a song or dance. What's your favorite song to sing or dance to?
